nodes.name: Radiational Psi
nodes.description: Psi have field properties and have radiational behavior

nodes.name: Non-local Psi
nodes.description: Psi have non-local behavior.

nodes.name: Unconscious Psi
nodes.description: Psi is a unconscious process

nodes.name: Magnetic Influence
nodes.description: Magnetism have influence over psi phenomena

nodes.name: Friend Psi
nodes.description: Nonintentional psi would be greater when helping a friend than when helping a stranger.

nodes.name: Cost-effetive psi
nodes.description: Nonintentional psi would be greater when the cost of helping was low than when the cost of helping was high.

nodes.name: Good Luck Belief
nodes.description: Belief in good luck is psi conductive.

nodes.name: Unintentional Psi
nodes.description: Psi phenomena can occour unintentionaly

nodes.name: Openness
nodes.description: Openness would correlate positively with psi.

nodes.name: Defensiveness (negative)
nodes.description: Neuroticism/Defensiveness would correlate negatively with psi.

nodes.name: Belief in Psi
nodes.description: Belief in Psi is psi conductive.

nodes.name: Extraversion
nodes.description: Extraversion is psi conductive

nodes.name: Defensiveness
nodes.description: Defensiveness if psi-conductive

nodes.name: Goal-Oriented
nodes.description:
Psi process is intrinsically goal-oriented
and that it, thereby, acts independently of task complexity

nodes.name: Tag Scanning
nodes.description: The activity of extrasensorially scanning the potentially relevant environment for potentially relevant information would, even if done unconsciously, seem to be formidable and costly in terms of processing capacity.

nodes.name: Needsubserving
nodes.description: Nonintentional psi is needsubserving

nodes.name: Psychosis
nodes.description: Paranormal experiences are sign of psychosis

nodes.name: Causality
nodes.description: a paranormal belief system could for some people, be used, as a cognitive defence against acceptance of the uncertainty of life events by creating meaningfulness out of coincidences or it could be indicative of psychopathology.

nodes.name: Cognitive Bias
nodes.description: paranormal belief systems help sustain psychic integrity and to do so they operate in practice as a cognitive bias

nodes.name: Illusion of Control
nodes.description:
Persons who believe they can control an event they in reality cannot control, might then be expected to show a healthier psychological
functioning than persons who (rightly) do not think they can control chance events

nodes.name: Reasoning Skills
nodes.description: It has been suggested that paranormal beliefs might be correlated with reasoning ability, especially when the reasoning task contains apparent paranormal content

nodes.name: Local Sideral Time
nodes.description: The local sidereal time (the time at which a particular part of the sky is directly overhead) may correlate with psi score

nodes.name: Shannon Entropy
nodes.description: The gradient of Shannon entropy of targets (images or videos) may correlate with psi

nodes.name: Quality of Randomness
nodes.description: The Quality of Randomness of the target may affect psi score.

nodes.name: Emotional Bound
nodes.description: Emotional bount between people is conductive to "extrassensorial communication"

nodes.name: Inacurate Recall
nodes.description: Cognitive Psychologists that people recall of everyday events can be highly inaccurate. Once a particular interpretation is placed in the event, features of the experience consistent with that interpretation tend to be recalled but inconsistente features will tend to be forgotten

nodes.name: Human Psi
nodes.description: Some humans can produce psi phenomena.

nodes.name: All Humans
nodes.description:
All Humans can produce psi phenomena.

Some surveys points that a great percentage of people acknoledged some psi experience.

nodes.name: Gifted Human
nodes.description: Only some gifted people can produce psi phenomena

nodes.name: Animal Psi
nodes.description: Some animals can produce psi phenomena

nodes.name: Evolutive Psi
nodes.description: Psi was created in the evolutionary process

nodes.name: Context-Dependent Anomalous Cognition
nodes.description: Umbrella hypothesis that psi-like effects, if real, are weak, probabilistic, and strongly dependent on participant selection, protocol quality, and context.

nodes.name: Ganzfeld: small positive signal in registered-report synthesis
nodes.description: Represents Ganzfeld evidence suggesting a small aggregate positive signal under some designs, with ongoing debate about robustness and moderators.

nodes.name: Presentiment: anticipatory physiology claims
nodes.description: Represents presentiment claims where pre-stimulus physiology appears to anticipate random future stimuli, with unresolved artifact and preprocessing concerns.

nodes.name: RNG micro-PK: tiny effects with fragility concerns
nodes.description: Represents RNG micro-PK findings with very small effects that are sensitive to study design, publication bias, and replication quality.

nodes.name: Non-signaling constrained nonlocal models
nodes.description: Represents nonlocal models constrained by no-signaling: correlation-like effects without controllable faster-than-light information transfer.

nodes.name: Protocol quality and transparency as effect moderators
nodes.description: Represents the claim that preregistration, blinding, randomization quality, and transparency strongly modulate observed effect size estimates.

nodes.name: Publication bias and selective reporting
nodes.description: Represents inflation risks from selective reporting, analytic flexibility, and publication bias in weak-signal literatures.

nodes.name: Expectation/order artifacts
nodes.description: Represents conventional expectation, order, and preprocessing artifacts that can mimic anticipatory or anomalous effects.

nodes.name: Illusory control and reasoning-bias pathway
nodes.description: Represents cognitive mechanisms such as illusory control and reasoning errors that increase anomalous interpretation without anomalous transfer.

nodes.name: False memory and magical ideation pathway
nodes.description: Represents memory distortion and ontological confusion pathways associated with stronger paranormal belief.

nodes.name: Null-heavy replication outcomes
nodes.description: Represents the empirical pattern of null or near-null outcomes in many high-powered and transparent replications.

nodes.name: Classical carrier constraints: attenuation and shielding
nodes.description: Represents physical constraints such as attenuation, shielding, energetic plausibility, and gravity-speed bounds on classical carrier psi models.

nodes.name: Bell nonlocality does not imply controllable signaling
nodes.description: Represents the distinction that Bell nonlocality supports nonlocal correlations but not controllable signaling channels.

nodes.name: Retrocausal claims challenged by modern replications
nodes.description: Represents retrocausal and precognition claims weighed against modern replication failures and statistical critiques.

nodes.name: Holographic/holorresonance framing as heuristic
nodes.description: Represents holographic and holorresonance-style frameworks as heuristic organizing models pending stronger discriminative predictions.

references.title: Parapsychological phenomena and the absorption domain
references.publication: Journal of the American Society for Psychical Research
references.citation: Irwin, Harvey J. (1985). Parapsychological phenomena and the absorption domain. Journal of the American Society for Psychical Research, 79, 1-11.

references.title: Magical thinking in formal operational adults
references.citation: Lesser, R. & Paisner, M. (1985). Magical thinking in formal operational adults.Human Development, 28, 57-70.

references.title: Wings of Illusion
references.citation: Schumaker, J.F. (1990). Wings of Illusion. Cambridge: Polity Press.

references.title: Illusion of control for self and others in depressed and non-depressed college students
references.publication: Journal of Personality and Social Psychology
references.citation: Martin, D.J. ; Abramson, L.Y. & Alloy, L.B. (1984). Illusion of control for self and others in depressed and non-depressed college students.Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 46, 125-136.

references.title: Reasoning errors and belief in the paranormal
references.citation: Wierzbicki, M. (1985). Reasoning errors and belief in the paranormal.Journal of Social Psychology, 125, 489-494.

references.title:
Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental
Disorders
references.citation: American Psychiatric Association. (1994). Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders.Washington, DC:American Psychiatric Association.

references.title: Conscious vs. unconscious clairvoyance in the context of an academic examination
references.citation: Braud, W. G. (1975). Conscious vs. unconscious clairvoyance in the context of an academic examination.Journal of Parapsychology, 39, 277-288.

references.title: Comparison of PK action on two different random number generators
references.citation: Schmidt, H. (1974). Comparison of PK action on two different random number generators.Journal of Parapsychology, 38, 47-55.

references.title: Toward a mathematical theory of psi
references.citation: Schmidt, H. (1975). Toward a mathematical theory of psi.Journal of Parapsychology, 69, 301-319.

references.title: Experimental study of complexity dependence in precognition
references.citation: Vassy, Z. (1986). Experimental study of complexity dependence in precognition.Journal of Parapsychology, 50, 235-270.

references.title: Stage 2 Registered Report: Anomalous perception in a Ganzfeld condition - A meta-analysis of more than 40 years investigation
references.citation: Meta-analysis of 113 studies (1974-2020) reports small positive effect (~0.08) with moderator effects and bias checks.
references.abstract: Large registered-report synthesis finding a small but nonzero overall effect in Ganzfeld databases and stronger effects in selected participants.

references.title: Meta-analysis of free-response studies, 1992-2008: assessing the noise reduction model in parapsychology
references.citation: Meta-analysis reports positive effects in ganzfeld and some noise-reduction paradigms.
references.abstract: Influential synthesis suggesting positive free-response effects but later challenged on randomization and robustness grounds.

references.title: Meta-analysis that conceals more than it reveals: comment on Storm et al. (2010)
references.citation: Critical commentary arguing evidence remains unpersuasive absent independently replicable results.
references.abstract: Methodological critique emphasizing that meta-analytic significance alone is insufficient without robust independent replication.

references.title: Feeling the future: experimental evidence for anomalous retroactive influences on cognition and affect
references.publication: Journal of Personality and Social Psychology
references.citation: Nine experiments reported mean effect size d=0.22 for retroactive influence claims.
references.abstract: Landmark controversial paper reporting retroactive facilitation effects and motivating large-scale replication efforts.

references.title: Correcting the past: failures to replicate ψ
references.publication: Journal of Personality and Social Psychology
references.citation: Seven replication studies and follow-up meta-analysis reported average effect d=0.04, not different from zero.
references.abstract: High-powered replication program that failed to reproduce key retroactive facilitation findings from Bem (2011).

references.title: Why psychologists must change the way they analyze their data: the case of psi
references.publication: Journal of Personality and Social Psychology
references.citation: Bayesian reanalysis argues evidence in Bem's data is weak to nonexistent.
references.abstract: Statistical critique highlighting exploratory flexibility and arguing that one-sided p-values overstated evidential strength.

references.title: A Bayes factor meta-analysis of Bem's ESP claim
references.citation: Bayesian assessment across experiments; interpretation differs from both strong-pro and strong-con readings.
references.abstract: Meta-analytic Bayes factor approach showing how prior choices and aggregation strategy materially alter inference strength.

references.title: Raising the value of research studies in psychological science by increasing the credibility of research reports: the transparent Psi project
references.citation: Multi-lab transparent replication of Bem Experiment 1 found 49.89% hits vs 50% chance.
references.abstract: Demonstrates an intensive transparency protocol and reports null replication for the flagship Bem task.

references.title: Stage 1 Registered Report: Anomalous perception in a Ganzfeld condition - A meta-analysis of more than 40 years investigation
references.citation: Pre-registered protocol and analysis plan for long-horizon Ganzfeld synthesis.
references.abstract: Protocol-first phase that improves auditability of inclusion criteria and analyses before final synthesis.

references.title: Predictive physiological anticipation preceding seemingly unpredictable stimuli: a meta-analysis
references.citation: Meta-analysis of 26 reports suggests pre-stimulus physiological differences before random events.
references.abstract: Frequently cited presentiment synthesis reporting anomalous anticipatory physiological effects.

references.title: We should have seen this coming
references.citation: Editorial critique of presentiment analyses emphasizing expectation, trial-order and preprocessing artifacts.
references.abstract: Argues that extraordinary temporal claims require stronger controls and direct tests of conventional artifact explanations.

references.title: Examining psychokinesis: the interaction of human intention with random number generators--a meta-analysis
references.citation: 380 RNG studies showed tiny overall effect with heterogeneity and small-study patterns consistent with bias.
references.abstract: Classic RNG-PK synthesis often interpreted as evidence of weak effects but strong vulnerability to publication and selection bias.

references.title: Loophole-free Bell inequality violation using electron spins separated by 1.3 kilometres
references.citation: Loophole-free Bell test rejected local realism under strict conditions.
references.abstract: Confirms nonlocal quantum correlations while not establishing controllable faster-than-light communication channels.

references.title: Quantum field theory cannot provide faster-than-light communication
references.citation: Formal argument that QFT cannot be used for superluminal signaling.
references.abstract: Theoretical no-signaling constraint often cited to distinguish correlation nonlocality from actionable communication.

references.title: Gravitational Waves and Gamma-rays from a Binary Neutron Star Merger: GW170817 and GRB 170817A
references.citation: Joint detection constrains speed difference between gravity and light to around 10^-15.
references.abstract: Multi-messenger constraints substantially reduce plausibility of many superluminal or exotic carrier models.

references.title: AWAreness during REsuscitation - II: A multi-center study of consciousness and awareness in cardiac arrest
references.citation: In-hospital arm: no correct visual target identifications; limited auditory hit.
references.abstract: High-control prospective design in extreme-consciousness context with very limited objective target-identification support.

references.title: Paranormal beliefs and core knowledge confusions: A meta-analysis
references.citation: Meta-analysis across 25 effects found robust association (r≈0.40) between paranormal belief and ontological confusions.
references.abstract: Supports cognitive-style pathways that can explain paranormal conviction without requiring real anomalous information transfer.

references.title: Superstition predicts perception of illusory control
references.citation: Laboratory contingency task: superstition scores predicted stronger illusion of causality.
references.abstract: Shows a measurable cognitive mechanism linking superstition with over-attribution of control in random environments.

references.title: Publication bias is bad for science if not necessarily scientists
references.citation: Bayesian modeling paper clarifies why publication bias distorts field-level inference even with partially rational readers.
references.abstract: Metascience analysis reinforcing why weak-effect literatures require strong anti-bias infrastructure.
